Title: untitled #001 Fandom: Prince of Tennis Pairing: I dunno. Tezuka/Ryoma if you look closely? Author: Lindra () Author's Notes: tennis really says everything in this series, doesn't it? first. Echizen requires more than one language just to say all the things he doesn't say, but only one to say everything. It's the sort of thought that comes out of nowhere, assaults Tezuka with absolutely no foundation to prove it. It's not a thought Inui would have, or Fuji, or any of the others. Atobe would, but then Atobe has played Echizen at this point, and it is only when you play Echizen that this sort of thing can be learnt. That the mention of Atobe in any relation to Echizen irritates him isn't worth thinking about, so he takes the point and goes with it. If he thinks about it a little more, Echizen and language and English and Japanese, what's said in Echizen's cap and elbows, he comes to the conclusion that Echizen could be mute and illiterate, and it wouldn't matter. That's assuming he bothers to think about it. He doesn't at the time, but remembers it five days later at training and follows the thought as a way to distract himself. It wouldn't matter because - Tezuka isn't Inui. It just feels right to say: tennis and leave it at that, ungrammatical and incomplete to anyone else. second. Tezuka speaks in a language of his own, sometimes, one that's not tennis or anything he's learnt. It's a fragile little language, a dialect of Echizen's doing, but it's growing and he can feel it smiling inside of him, bonding with what he is to have him become something uncertain and greater. It's composed of what he says in wristbands and intensity and practicing the occassional strange-feeling smile in the train window; what he feels when Echizen discovers something new and greater in himself, his pride in Seigaku, in all of them. It breaks and stretches inside him, pushes him a little off-balance. He feels more confident than he did before, and at the same time more uncertain. Tezuka accepts this as a simple question of balance. last. Give this new development a year, he thinks, and he just might dare to laugh in practice, in truth, instead of the occassional chuckle inside his mind. He'd like to think that Echizen would laugh, if he laughed. If he did, they would react like so: Eiji would think he had been replaced with some other strange creature, of course, and drape himself over someone, and Kawamura would worry and rub his neck, and Oishi would ask him if he were alright, and Kaidoh would look at him like the world had wobbled off course, and Fuji would smile with his eyes open, and Momo would dive into excited conference with Eiji. More data for Inui, but Tezuka suspects that Inui would spare him the sort of smile that was rarer than Fuji's honest one before Inui thought wrote anything down. He knows this, knows this of them. But even so, he likes to think that Echizen would, after the customary is buchou crazy moment, understand and laugh with him in the midst of it all.
Title: untitled #002 Fandom: Prince of Tennis Pairing: Tezuka/Ryoma. Again. Author: Lindra () Author's Notes: this started somewhere and ended up somewhere else. as what happens pretty much all the time. The first sign that something is wrong comes one afternoon when Eiji bounces over to where he is stretching and says 'Buchou told me to tell you that Ryuzsaki-sensei wants to talk to you.' Ryoma glances over to Tezuka and Inui standing by the fence. Inui seems to be doing a lot of talking, but Tezuka is too, and Inui doesn't look happy. 'Why didn't he tell me himself?' If Eiji is intimidating when they are standing, he is even more unnerving when he's leaning over Ryoma, hands on hips and beaming. 'No idea. Inui's not letting him get anywhere, nya.' Ryoma nods and lets it go, and Eiji wanders off to Oishi. When did Tezuka stop looking at him? The second sign is when Fuji pauses in the middle of practice and gives him a thoughtful look that wasn't along the lines of Fuji's usual consideration, but more puzzled, like he couldn't figure something out. It's not a good sign for him when it comes down to it. A curious Fuji -- curious enough to let him know he was curious, and not in a way that said he was plotting something -- was a rare enough thing that Ryoma became very careful to say and do as little as possible. The third is when Inui pulls out a notbook that has more tape along the spine than the rest of them and says 'Calculated height difference: precisely twenty-eight centimetres.' and Ryoma doesn't have to ask who he's talking about. Somehow, that fact catches him by the ear and jerks him around until he's looking up at Inui, who looks back and continues, 'He will have to bend approximately thirty degrees. I recommend sitting down.' It's horrifying and relieving all at once that Inui knows, and he knows that Inui's helping in Inui-fashion, but still. Inui knows. Somehow the mildly sympathetic expression on Inui's face is even worse. The fourth is when he passes Sanada on some random street on some random day and some impulse tells him to open his mouth before his brain can overrule the idea and say 'How did you deal with Yukimura?' Sanada's face stiffens, and Ryoma watches the glimpse of panic snap off Sanada's face to reveal nothing. 'I was careful,' Sanada says at last, and not for the first time, Ryoma admires his voice, deep and steady. 'But it was more within his control than mine.' Then, 'Captains are often difficult when they are not easily persuaded.' 'But what do you do when they won't even look at you?' Sanada's face arranges itself into something like humour, except that it's Sanada. 'You're asking about the beginning.' Ryoma nods carefully. 'What happened first?' 'The first thing,' and it's more thoughtful than anything else, 'was when he defeated me in a match.' Ryoma watches Sanada's face carefully, and nods at the answers there. 'Echizen?' 'What?' 'We never had this conversation.' The fifth sign is when Tezuka is on his doorstep at half seven on a Wednesday night looking harassed and tired and too much like a salaryman. 'Echizen. Ryuszaki-sensei requested that this be handed to you.' There's a bunch of paper in his hands, and he's not sure if he took it from Tezuka or if Tezuka put it in his hands or maybe both. 'Buchou?' Tezuka waits, and it's the sort of visual trick that only Tezuka can pull off successfully, that sense of you are wasting my time. 'What is it, Echizen?' Ryoma tries to think of something to say that doesn't sound ridiculous. 'Play a match with me.' The sixth and final sign is when Tezuka is standing on the court, objections running across his face without needing to be said homework council duties paperwork tests sleep, and he lets Ryoma pull him down and kiss him. 'Thanks,' Ryoma mutters, and hastily moves away to his side of the court, but he can already feel the pull of having touched-kissed Tezuka once, and wanting to do it again. There's something addictive and powerful about being that close to Tezuka, not necessarily kissing him but just having touched him. Tezuka's eyes are very clear and Ryoma's stomach is complaining when it comes to game and match, and Ryoma's worries fall into place at the sound of Tezuka's bag being hoisted. 'Don't send messengers, buchou.' 'Don't involve Sanada, Echizen.' 'Che.'
Title: untitled #003 Fandom: Prince of Tennis Pairing: eventual Tezuka/Ryoma. Author: Lindra () Author's Notes: Fuji is evil. The first time Ryoma is given a box to stand on in photographs, the others snicker and shrug and point to Fuji, who calmly took a photograph without the box,and then with, and showed the two results to him with the sense of a foregone conclusion. Despite all the arguments Ryoma can think of, the box becomes a fixture in the clubhouse, and he's merely grateful that there aren't very many photographs taken that require him to be standing with the others. Of course, it doesn't help much at tournaments, so he scowls and ensures that he is standing with Inui and Tezuka. They make anyone look short, and if he has to be short, then he'll be short. It works for a while, until Inui comments that he's gotten taller and that the optical trick won't work anymore, and Ryoma finds that if he stands next to Eiji and Oishi instead, he can appear just a little below average. Then he grows again, and by this time he has to buy another jacket and opponents mutter that they heard he was shorter, and he can stand with Kaidoh and Momo as a buffer of indifference. In the end, Inui's chin rests comfortably on his head and Fuji can't claim that Ryoma is too short for Tezuka anymore. Neither can Tezuka.

Title: Letting Go Fandom: Prince of Tennis Pairing: Fuji-matchmaker {sort of); implied TezuRyo Author: Lindra () Author's Notes: I seem to have a run of Fuji-POV TezuRyo lately. I imagine this one to be set about five years after Tezuka's left Seigaku, and for Tezuka and Fuji to be first-year university students (why that is... well, that is another fic altogether). As always, unbeta'ed; and as always, for Aja.
He glances up and across at Tezuka, about to ask regarding a certain formula Tezuka grasps better than he does, and pauses. Tezuka's expression has a particular brooding, curious look to it, and his face is turned all angles and curves and his eyes are so bright, knife edge bright, and it's painfully obvious who Tezuka's thinking about. 'Tezuka.' Tezuka's head moves a little, his eyes glance towards Fuji; but the look is still there, it is not Fuji or the cupboards behind him that Tezuka is looking at, and Fuji sets down his cup of tea, shifts his weight, smiles. 'You can't stop, can you?' The look is gone, then, and Tezuka straightens, looks squarely across the table at him, cheap overhead light casting frames onto his glasses, his left hand flat on top of the cracked table. 'No.' 'Just go find him,' Fuji advises, holding back irritation, the urge to defend Tezuka to himself; it won't do any good, it'll make things worse. Then, sharply, just as sharp as Fuji intends -- to get Tezuka to do anything, you have to hurt him -- 'What are you waiting for?' Tezuka takes a quick breath that catches in his throat, leans back and folds his arms across his chest. Fuji sways closer, watches Tezuka breathe for a moment before continuing; his breath smells like tea and pity. 'Here.' He unfolds the paper in his hand, puts it on the table with a finger on top so Tezuka can't take it and throw it away as Tezuka will inevitably do if Fuji lets him. 'His address, his phone number. I called him.' Tezuka's eyes narrow, and Fuji can see the ghost of forty laps on his tongue, but he is no longer buchou, they are no longer part of Seigaku, and Fuji was never his in the first place. 'He asked after you,' he says, and it's like he's answered a prayer; Tezuka's chin softens, and there's something like hope in the twist of his hands, and Fuji thinks: Finally. 'Call him,' and it's Fuji's blessing and Tezuka's release, and Tezuka's hand is flat over the paper and Fuji's scrawled handwriting -- he had repeated his details three times, two of those unnecessary, just to make sure Fuji had everything correct -- as he looks across at Fuji. Fuji flicks at the back of Tezuka's hand and kisses him a final time, presses his lips to Tezuka's cheek. Fuji can feel Tezuka withdraw from him, feels their existence togther crash and burn and take Fuji with it, and knows that it's the right thing to do, the only thing to do. As Fuji packs, he can imagine perfectly the stance that Tezuka is in now, Tezuka standing in the hall in front of the phone on the creaky board and shifting his weight, crrrrreeeekcriicreeeekcriicreeek, and staring at the paper crinkled in his hand; just as he does every other time Fuji does this, finds a phone number and an address and presses it on Tezuka, Oishi or Eiji or Taka. And just as he does every other time, he will be himself again, himself being Tezuka-buchou. Tezuka can never be anything else, and to pretend otherwise is delusion. This is the first time it's been Echizen's information on the paper, and it's the last piece of knowledge that Fuji has to give. He packs away his photos, his albums, takes all of them except the ones of Seigaku and Echizen, sweeps his clothes and shoes into a bag, unhurried as Tezuka's British-accented Japanese English drifts under the door, shifts to easy, familiar Japanese. Fuji walks past, bag in hand; he's never kept much at Tezuka's flat anyway, never bothered to, always knowing that someday he'd leave like this, and Tezuka blinks at him, then understands in the fraction of a second it takes for Fuji to lean forwards and say into the reciever, 'Echizen, remember, buchou needs planting in a sunny spot and watering every morning.' Echizen's mutter of 'Fuji-senpai...' is familiar, as is the look on Tezuka's face -- exactly as Fuji has imagined it for years -- as Fuji smiles with his eyes closed and leaves, Tezuka's happiness flaring in his mind, illuminating and not entirely welcome in its scorching brightness. He can imagine Echizen's voice. Buchou, are you there? He can hear Tezuka's response, quiet and certain. 'I'm here,' and it's finally the truth.

Title: a square and a circle and a line Fandom: Prince of Tennis Pairing: Tezuka/Ryoma through Fuji POV Author: Lindra Author's Notes: Originally written as a comment to Aja as a bribe, which was then refused, and as the idea was already half-written, turned into a present instead. Massively unbeta'ed, like everything else I post.
Tezuka is to Fuji is as Fuji is to cactus. It's not the best analogy in Fuji's mind. The fact remains that Tezuka fills a very specific purpose in Fuji's life -- one that he seems to take without complaint -- and Fuji fills an important role in Tezuka's life. It works, somehow. It's one of the more surprising things that came out of when they first met; that the arrangement, on the whole, works. When Fuji calls Tezuka, he knows that Tezuka will hang up on him if he asks Tezuka logical but idiotic questions -- as, say, Inui does -- so it's much better to talk, back and forth, around and through and under a topic, and then toss in an illogical, reasonable question that smacks of Yumiko's perception being a familial inheritance. It'll be the kind of question that doesn't require words, just the change in Tezuka's breathing, changes in his voice and presence and how Fuji can hear his hand shift on the reciever. Tezuka is to Fuji as squares are to circles. To Fuji's mind, it's prettier when the squares are inside the circles, and that is exactly where Tezuka ends up being. It's useful knowledge, in a sort of desultory this-is-how-it-is way. Lately, though, Echizen. Echizen. And now Tezuka's hand clenches in time to echizen ryoma echizen ryoma when Fuji mentions him -- he doubts that Tezuka notices, but then again maybe he does -- and Tezuka is stacked inside Fuji's grasp and Ryoma is a long, straight line down the middle of Tezuka's square, with no beginning or end except Tezuka himself. And the rest of the team, orbiting them without knowing. But Echizen dived right to the centre of their formation, where he is safe and he never loses (except to Sanada, and once; Fuji pried that particular fact out of Kawamura one night, and was almost glad) and Fuji knows that Echizen knows that as long as Echizen is Tezuka's to hold and guard and protect and above all shove forward like a parent at the end of his tether (and Tezuka wears out his tether a lot when it comes to Echizen), Fuji will not harm him. Not seriously. Not in the spirit of, say, Kirihara, or Mizuki. Not in that sense of needing to defend and protect against physical harm. He's always had a particular soft spot for Tezuka, for captains that lead by example and faith (tezuka) (tachibana) -- but it's Tezuka that concerns him now, Tezuka's need is a little too strong, a little too desperate, for Fuji's taste, and so Fuji does his best to blur the edges. Blunt edges cause the most pain and damage, but they are slower, and he hopes that Echizen will realise this before Tezuka is hurt. Fuji will watch and wait and make ridiculously insightful comments at and to Tezuka late at night while Tezuka does his history homework, and he enjoys listening to Tezuka's breath jump, the sudden screech of his pen. Fuji will watch and needle Echizen ever so slightly until Echizen raises his cap and glares, but he will do nothing beyond that. Really, it was his own fault, pure and simple. Fuji's fault that Tezuka was so intrigued, so easily snared by Echizen (he'd set up that particular failing a long time ago by thoroughly disappointing Tezuka at every opportunity when it came to displaying his skill, and it was more fun than he'd had in the previous year) and his fault that Echizen was attatched to Tezuka for most of practice and games in his constant unconscious efforts to make Tezuka smile however he could (also his fault; Fuji had informed Tezuka, halfway through their second year, that Tezuka was irresistible when he smiled, so now Tezuka did his best not to and in retrospect, punning on the Tezuka Zone that had been in action at the time was a bad idea). In a way, Fuji was like -- no, Fuji was the circle around them, the square and the line without beginning or end. And like the circle that bound them all, he did his best to hold Tezuka and Echizen together, just because it was more fun to see them together than apart -- although their being apart for a little while every so often was an excellent opportunity to drop cryptic remarks and watch them both stiffen and try to hide the fact that they'd reacted at all, Tezuka succeeding much better than Echizen -- and, well, it was better for them anyway. Besides, this way, he got to take pictures and drop them in their lockers every so often when they weren't looking. Just to remind them that he was there.

Title: Paperclips Fandom: Prince of Tennis Pairing: Tezuka/Ryoma Author: Lindra () Author's Notes: Thanks to for dragging me into the fandom; thanks to for the once-over. This was written very, very quickly; I estimate about fifteen-twenty minutes in total, and was originally meant to be a drabble, but it spiraled. For Aja. ♥
Some days, Tezuka's hair is one of the most annoying things in the world. It sticks up all over the place, but it doesn't. It's flat, and it's upright, and it's not, and there's the occassional thought somewhere that Tezuka's morning hair must be fantastic, but he shoves that idea away without too much difficulty. (It still nags, though, when he sees Tezuka with a towel around his neck. If he dared to reach up and throw it over Tezuka's head and scrub...) And today, it is especially annoying, because the ends stick out and tickle his nose and the skin between his eyebrows, and being tickled makes kissing difficult, given that Ryoma's internal response is for his stomach to curdle and his face to go perfectly blank. Neither of these things help kissing, and eventually, he shoves Tezuka's face away and grabs for some paperclips off Tezuka's desk. 'Echizen--' 'Hold still,' Ryoma mutters, and he's aware that he's crawling all over Tezuka, that his knees must be digging into Tezuka's thighs and hurting an awful lot, and if he slipped, Tezuka would be extremely angry at him. He's also aware of Tezuka's minute, puzzled confusion (don't look at his eyebrows for that, look at his eyes, the angle of his wrists in his pockets) and of the fact that when Ryoma told him to hold still, he held still immediately and without another word. It's a wonder of the world. He's finished, eventually, and when he wriggles his way back into his awkward place on Tezuka's lap, Tezuka looks startled and faintly annoyed and Tezuka with a forehead is a new look, Ryoma thinks, and it's not the best job ever, but it's enough. Ryoma leans in to kiss Tezuka, but is stopped by a hand on his shoulder. 'What?' He's impatient now; his lips are getting cold. 'Did you just decorate my hair with paperclips?' His voice is very careful, as though what on earth has Echizen done now? has been taken to another level, and it probably has. 'It was getting in the way.' This time, Ryoma does kiss him, and Tezuka makes no attempt to stop him, and he can taste confusion and the the faint withdrawl that means Tezuka's not paying attention. He knocks on the side of Tezuka's head. 'Stop thinking,' he scolds, and Tezuka murmurs something about laps, and starts to voice another question. 'Echizen--' 'Thinking!' Ryoma cuts him off with a squirm in his lap, pulls Tezuka closer. 'I told you, stop thinking.' He presses a hard kiss to his mouth. 'Do it tomorrow,' he adds and finishes, and this kiss is Tezuka's lead, and Ryoma follows eagerly. (Definitely paying attention now, and Ryoma can tell by how both arms are pulling him close, can tell by the expression in Tezuka's eyes, the plea in how his spine arches into Ryoma's hands.) Tezuka's expression the next morning at practice when Fuji's smile is broader and more secrective than usual is wary and exasperated, and his expression when he discovers Kaidoh and Inui hastily conferring in the locker room is one that orders them onto the courts, now. But best of all is the threat of payback in his face when Eiji points out the last paperclip clinging to the back of his hair and he fails to react, just calmly picks it out and puts it in his pocket and orders twenty laps like it's an afterthought. A little later, in the middle of Ryoma's twelfth lap, he directs his glare at Ryoma, narrows his eyes and tilts his jaw and promises it will be your turn with every line of his body, and Ryoma returns it with i'll be waiting. Tezuka stops him at the end of practice, stops him by coming up behind him and Ryoma turns around before anything is said; Tezuka measures Ryoma with his eyes like he does every time he sees him, and tosses the paperclip at him. Ryoma catches it easily and stares up at his captain. 'Buchou?' 'Return it to me later,' is all he says, and he walks away with Fuji (he's convinced for half a second that Fuji knows, convinced, and then when Fuji's face turns away, he's not so sure anymore, but he can still see that smile in front of him). It's an invitation, it's challenge and anticipation, and it's so like Tezuka it hurts. It goes without saying that Tezuka will bring the balls, Ryoma will bring himself (and the paperclip), and for a little while, nothing else will matter. He doesn't need to answer Tezuka, with words or anything else. They both already know, and by the next month, the paperclip is brittle from being passed back and forth between them, heavy with newly formed tradition and all the things left unsaid.
